help.name: American Cancer Society
help.description: 866-784-8454 (avaliable 24 hours a day, 7 days a week (with exception to national holidays)

help.name: National Cancer Institute
help.description: 877-448-7848 (avaliable 8 AM to 8 PM ET, Monday through Friday) + Live online chat assistance available 8 AM to 11 PM ET, Monday through Friday

help.name: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services

contacts.name: World Health Organization (WHO) - Tobacco Free Initiative
contacts.description: The WHO's Tobacco Free Initiative is one of the leading global organizations dedicated to reducing tobacco use and the dangers with it. They offer multiple resources and campaigns to help promote tobacco control

contacts.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) - Office on Smoking and Health (OSH)
contacts.description: The CDC's Office on Smoking and Health (OSH) focuses on researching, educating, and developing policies in relation to tobacco control within the United States. They provide information on quitting smoking, tobacco-related data, and resources for getting involved in tobacco control initiatives

contacts.name: Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids
contacts.description: The Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids is dedicated to reducing tobacco use specifically among youth populations and advocating for the implementation of tobacco control policies worldwide. They work on various campaigns and initiatives to promote tobacco control

contacts.name: American Cancer Society - Tobacco and Cancer
contacts.description: The American Cancer Society (ACS) offers resources and information on the relationship between tobacco use and cancer. They advocate for tobacco control policies and support tobacco cessation efforts

contacts.name: Action on Smoking and Health (ASH)
contacts.description: ASH is a nonprofit organization that focuses on eliminating the harm caused by tobacco use. They work to influence public policy, promote smoke-free environments, and support evidence-based tobacco control measures
